job_title: Warehouse Fullfilment Associate in Carteret, NJ
pros: Benefits. PTO. Zero Experience Required. No Interview. No Resume. You would think that we so much grow the company would not hesitate to create programs to make you learn skills such as programming or something else so you can move up several dollars in wages. But no such programs exist. You see faces every week come and go. Algorithms dictate that no such thing as change is necessary. Is a good job as long they hire throughout the year as a emergency "cash gig". Most organizations live in the Stone Age with their "required" experience needed, plus resume, plus interviews. Seriously, manual work unless is very specific skill like a dentist needs intensive training. Then you have your self important "manager" who's held up to a very important status in most companies. Well, here too, But his ego not his pay is not so peculiarly so important. This place is a revolving door. Lots of not so hard working persons sort of fire themselves after learning that working hard here is the norm. Yet some of these persons strive to stay here without being too bothered. Most senior people I talked to have less than a year here. And these group is very tiny. Incredible approach to start you with benefits if you are full-time from day 1. Most companies make you wait 90 days. Keep in mind that Amazon 401K is NOT vested. So if you quit in a year or two, the Amazon share of the 401k plan is NOT yours to keep. Geez, high tech and all. Yet they don't have a program to move up substantially in training and pay. Like a $35-50 HOUR jobs. They hire people from abroad for those jobs I guess. In the upcoming future 7-10 years. Most people, even the managers maybe replaced by more robots. Seriously. Benefits are great. Paying like $15 for $250K of life insurance. I never seen this elsewhere.
cons: No room to advance. Car Pool or Transportation Incentives Don't Exist. Hard Work. Eventually you get tired, fired or just walk away of being tired, No immediate education to move UP really move UP several dollars in pay. They probably still sponsoring people from overseas to top paying jobs. No need to train you so you can seriously advance.

pros: Good pay after you hit level 5. Everything before it is like a probationary period. It is competitive but mostly with yourself and you will work with some of the best people in the world inside a warehouse.
cons: The culture is harsh and takes some getting used to direct feedback as being part of your normal routine. My advice is to never take it personally because it's not. job_title: Senior Developer Advocate in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Pay seems worth it. Lots of great opportunities and autonomy. Great people. Great technology stack
cons:
You have to be type A and constantly charging forward. No hand holding. If you’re getting back into the workforce after a long stint of freelance or non-traditional environments... it’s like shell shock. A lot of responsibilities and you’re only really given feedback, not permission or guidance. So if you can’t fair in that kind of environment, or if you have more bad days than good - your performance reviews are going to gut you. 

Basically, have constant focus, energy, drive, passion, and communicate clearly..all the time. Build relationships. It’s a sink or swim environment.

pros: The flexibility of the schedule when they want it to be. Free life insurance policy Dental insurance.
cons: One of the worst working environments you can endure. You find yourself hoping for VTO(Voluntary Time Off) because you would rather starve or deprive yourself of something than to deal with coworkers and management. They will have you sorting mail that ranges from a little envelope to a 45 lb weight on 3 different lanes during the night shift the volume is in the 100 of thousands and you get like 10 lanes each lane has 2 destinations with 20 different bags on each not including the oversized packages so if you are a “STOWER” do the math at night shift it is your responsibility to to sort mail for 10 lanes those 10 lanes rep 2 different destinations w 20 bags on each side 20x2x10= 400 bags your responsible for dividing mail into again not including an oversized package that can weigh up to 70 lbs. Safety protocol especially during Covid has been terrible. They hire people to be safety police which their job is to make sure you abide by the 6ft and mask over face rule. That’s fine but its contradicting when these saftey police people talk to one another without their mask on closer than 6 ft. These safety police people are basically another outlet for management to haggle regular associates because their position is distinguished by a different color vest so basically if you your vest has stripes it gives you the right to not wear your mask or be closer than 6 ft. Then of course this is your job all day and the people they give these jobs are the people that was shown favoritism And did nothing when they were regular associates. Another sign that they don’t care about your safety they allow delivery vans within the warehouse which they’re are stop signs ON THE WALK PATH! so basically it’s to say a 20,000 pound DELIVERY VAN has the right of way to walk instead of a human in Amazon eyes. They actually have associate that will stop you so the van can come inside think about it if your on the street a crosswalk guard mostly stop vehicles so the pedestrian can walk not in Amazon culture the delivery van has higher hierarchy than an associate. They don’t treat the drivers well either they rush them to get routes by yelling at them telling them they can’t take bathroom breaks at times. The people they assign on the pods, again regular associates that got favoritism did nothing that are promoted to a position to do what? Yes nothing. Their job is to help the drivers with their route but you will have a driver come up to you a person staging your route to ask the location of their route. So factor that in Amazon has employed a person to yell at this driver be the leader of the pod where their routes or staged but between these people the driver has to find an associate in middle of staging a route for assistance. Your schedule requests are never looked at I did a schedule request more than 4 months out it was never even reviewed they have HR in the office which when u go to them with a problem they direct you to the hr telephone number which defeats the point of HR having an office in that building. Back to the Covid procedure lol in the beginning we got hazard pay n unlimited excused absences without being penalized because if you are in fear or you or your family life you shouldn’t be forced to come into a working environment that averaged about 4-5 cases in a day in that one warehouse. The hazard pay and excused absences lasted a month which upon return of the attendance policy they made the policy stricter than before Covid meaning if your one min late you lose an entire hour of your Unpaid Time(the only vacation time you get because again they don’t look at your days off request and during these times there was 0 VTO) you lose an entire hour instead of 1 min which before if you were 1 min late you lost 1 minute of the unpaid time. One of the “Covid” Safety Precautions was that no more than one person can be in an aisle , that has 6 different 6 ft markers down. When your picking a route up to 4 different people can be assigned to this aisle which you watch one person pick their item down the aisle while you wait with the other 3 closer than 6 ft because with route assistance people(people that do nothing but watching how long it takes you to pick a route) and the delivery vans there would be more social distancing office you would allow 3 people in the aisle at the same time seeing as the markers on the ground distinguishes 36 ft between the aisle instead of you trying to find space with 3 people waiting for their turn down the aisle, a delivery van , delivery driver and route assistance person who’s not going to do anything, but stare at a computer screen. They have the capability to supply new sorting devices throughout the warehouse because of outdated ones but don’t put the same attention towards the restrooms as stalls have remained broken for months. Now you would think doing all this Amazon would show some gratuity and compassion to their workers for putting their life physical mental health on the line I was reading the bulletin board where it states that off duty workers have a 10 min limit of being on the premises meaning that if you are in the break room waiting for your Uber or outside waiting for your ride they have an associate That will approach you and ask you to leave the premises if it is longer than a 10 min wait, or if you catch the bus and arrive 30 mins early you have to wait somewhere else than the place your are about to risk your health at to work at. The California labor laws states that you are entitled to 10 min break if you work more than 4 hours on a shift than can be taking in between there has been instances where they have tried to tell me I couldn’t take a break which it never worked because I told them I read and know it’s against the law but I have heard from other associates they have told them the same. The opportunity for growth is very limited they promote the favorites that do nothing or sleep their way into position they turning down people with supervisor experience for 19-20 year fresh fast young girls with weeks of experience lol haha

pros: Day one benefits, competitive pay.
cons:
Everything else, literally. So here's what happened. I made the mistake of getting hurt and reporting it. I was accused of faking it by a member of Amcare while he tried to trick me into admitting I was faking. The knot in my spine says otherwise. After a month of physical therapy with NO progress on me healing instead of sending me to a specialist the doctor decides that I wasn't hurt at work that It was a pre-existing condition and I was sent back with no restrictions. 

ALSO, while I was going back and forth to the doctor I was under restrictions, one of which was no over time. I was hit repeatedly with "job abandonment" notices for not showing up on my over time day. I was dinged repeatedly, I'm literally negative 14 hours in UPT for leaving early and not working my extra hour of overtime each day and nobody seems willing to fix it.

I thought I was having a heart attack 2 weeks go and went to the emergency room. I emailed HR the moment I got home and explained to them what was happening. 4 hours later I got ANOTHER notice for job abandonment, I both called and emailed again and actually got an email reply back first stating to bring in proof of my E-room visit to HR. So I did, but on site HR didn't want it, they said take it to Amcare, Amcare said take it to HR,,, you see the problem with that?

I walked out tonight, I can't do the job and they won't cooperate with me. Either by bad communication, no communication, or just don't care. I'm NOT going to cripple myself for this company.

job_title: Warehouse Sortation Associate in Oklahoma City, OK
pros: good pay, ability to add hours
cons: It's really hard on the body. My wrists and shoulders have tendonitis after six months in a sort center. Most of the jobs involve repetitive motion and/or heavy lifting. Shifts are 3 to 5 hours. Be aware you're not going to be making much money if you have a lot of 3 hour shifts. During peak it will almost always be 5 hour shifts.

pros: work from home, team leaders are usually pretty awesome (Jackie Stout specifically)
cons: I was on the fast path to management, UNTIL Amazon de-specialized everything, making moving up the ladder and making a decent living near impossible. they paid minimum wage. You used to get 2 stock options per year (with a 2 year wait to vest), after the stocks went up in value, they took it down to 1 stock per year.
